trial_identification.studytitle: Cognitive Behaviour Therapy of Acute Stress Disorder
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised controlled trial to evaluate the effect of prolonged exposure versus cognitive restructuring versus wait-list to prevent posttraumatic stress disorder

interventions.interventions: The intervention comprises prolonged exposure or cognitive restructuring. Participants are given 5 weekly 90-minute sessions of prolonged exposure (imaginal exposure and in vivo exposure) or 5 weekly 90-minute sessions of cognitive restructuring. Exposure involves repeating trauma memories. Cognitive restructuring involves identification and correction of irrational thoughts.
interventions.comparator: The control condition involves patients in the wait list being assessed before treatment and re-assessed 6 weeks later.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Severity of posttraumatic stress symptoms measured by the Clinician Adminsitered PTSD Scale
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline, posttreatment ,and 6 months after treatment.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Depression (measured by the Beck Depression Inventory)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at posttreatment and 6 months after treatment finishes.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Anxiety (measured by the Beck Anxiety Inventory)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at posttreatment and 6 months after treatment finishes.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Inclusion criteria were that the patient had suffered a motor vehicle accident or nonsexual assault in the previous month and met full criteria for ASD.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Exclusion criteria included history of psychosis, organic brain syndrome, current substance dependence, borderline personality disorder, suicidal risk, inability to converse in English, or aged less than 17 years of age or more than 70 years of age.

trial_design.concealment: Allocation to treatment condition is conducted by a clinician via email who is independent of the study and the hospital site.
trial_design.sequence: Random number generation with stratification by ASD severity, gender, and type of trauma.
trial_design.designfeatures: All assessors are blind to treatment condition

fundingsource.fundingname: National Health and Medical Research Council

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Acute Stress Disorder is a psychiatric condition that develops after exposure to a traumatic event, and is strongly predictive of subsequent disorder. Although cognitive behaviour therapy effectively treats ASD, little is known about the optimal intervention strategies for treating ASD. This study will compare 5 weekly sessions of either prolonged exposure, cognitive restructuring, or wait -list to determine the relative efficacies in reducing posttraumatic stress disorder at 6 months follow-up.
